unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Complementary Events
question_text:
Suppose the complement of event $A$ is defined as the probability of $A$ not happening and has a probability of $1-P(A)$.
Complementary events

choices.text: Can be disjoint at times, but not necessarily all the time.

solution:
Two events are disjoint if they cannot happen at the same time, and two events are independent if knowing of one event does not change the probability of the other event occurring.

Complementary events are NEVER independent; knowing one of the events occurs drops the probability of the other event to 0.

Complementary events are ALWAYS disjoint. For example, a single roll of a normal six-sided die could not yield “get a 3
” and “not get a 3
” at the same time.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
